verses.text: After these things had been accomplished, the leaders came to me and said, "The people of Israel, the priests, and the Levites have not separated themselves from the peoples of the lands, whose abominations are like those of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Jebusites, the Ammonites, the Moabites, the Egyptians, and the Amorites.
verses.comment: Ezra learns that the people, including leaders, have intermarried with neighboring nations against God's commands. Compare with God's warning in Deut. 7:3-4.

verses.text: For they have taken some of their daughters as wives for themselves and for their sons, so that the holy seed has mixed itself with the peoples of the lands. And the officials and rulers have taken the lead in this unfaithfulness."
verses.comment: "Holy seed" indicates Israel's distinct calling (see Gen. 17:7), a foreshadowing of the spiritual family of God through Christ. Leaders' greater guilt is highlighted.

verses.text: When I heard this matter, I tore my garment and my cloak, pulled hair from my head and my beard, and sat down in dismay.
verses.comment: Ezra’s grief is displayed with dramatic gesture, a sign of repentance echoed throughout Scripture. See a similar reaction in Neh. 1:4.

verses.text: Then everyone who trembled at the words of the God of Israel, because of the unfaithfulness of the returned exiles, gathered around me while I sat appalled until the evening offering.
verses.comment: "Everyone who trembled" points to a remnant faithful to God’s Word. The "evening offering" marks the continual liturgical worship.

verses.text: At the time of the evening offering, I rose from my humiliation, with my garment and my cloak torn, and I fell on my knees and spread out my hands to the Lord my God.
verses.comment: Ezra’s posture of prayer—kneeling, hands spread—parallels Daniel 9. A pattern adopted in later Christian worship.

verses.text: And I said: "O my God, I am ashamed and humiliated to lift up my face to you, my God, for our iniquities have risen higher than our heads, and our guilt has grown up to the heavens.
verses.comment: Ezra’s prayer is communal, including himself in the people's guilt—an important model for intercessory prayer.

verses.text: From the days of our fathers to this day we have been in great guilt. Because of our iniquities, we—our kings and our priests—have been delivered into the hand of the kings of the lands, to the sword, to captivity, to plunder, and to utter shame, as it is this day.
verses.comment: Historical confession links present sin to the past, showing continuity. Shared failure among laity, royalty, and priesthood demonstrates corporate responsibility.

verses.text: But now for a brief moment favor has come from the Lord our God, to leave us a remnant and give us a secure foothold in His holy place, that our God may brighten our eyes and grant us a little reviving in our bondage.
verses.comment: "Remnant" language is key—used prophetically of Israel but fulfilled in the gathering of the universal people of God. Temple worship is central.

verses.text: For we are slaves; yet our God has not forsaken us in our slavery, but has extended to us His steadfast love before the kings of Persia, to grant us new life to rebuild the house of our God and to repair its ruins, and to give us protection in Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.comment: God’s mercy is experienced through providential rulers. "House of our God" anticipates the role of the Temple, with later fulfillment in the Body of Christ as the true Temple (see John 2:19-22).

verses.text: "And now, O our God, what shall we say after this? For we have abandoned Your commandments,
verses.comment: Acknowledgment of sin continues. Referencing communal confession (see Daniel 9:5), which is a liturgical act involving the whole people.

verses.text: which You commanded through Your servants the prophets, saying, 'The land you are entering to possess is a land polluted by the impurity of the peoples of the lands, with their abominations that have filled it from one end to the other with their uncleanness.'
verses.comment: Ezra quotes prophetic warnings, emphasizing transmission of God’s Word through ordained ministers—a continuing theme in God guiding His people.

verses.text: 'Therefore do not give your daughters to their sons, neither take their daughters for your sons, and never seek their peace or prosperity, so that you may be strong and eat the good of the land, and leave it as an inheritance to your children forever.'
verses.comment: Obedience leads to inheritance—both physically (the land) and spiritually (life in God's presence). This foreshadows the ultimate inheritance of the Kingdom (Matt. 5:5).

verses.text: And after everything that has come upon us for our evil deeds and our great guilt—since You, our God, have punished us less than our iniquities deserved and have given us such a remnant as this—
verses.comment: God’s mercy is emphasized—the punishment is less than deserved. The gift of a remnant prefigures grace prevailing over judgment.

verses.text: shall we again break Your commandments and intermarry with the peoples who do these abominations? Would You not be angry with us until You consumed us, so that there would be no survivor or remnant?
verses.comment: Renewed sin could cost the entire corporate body its ability to continue as God’s faithful people—a warning for all ages.

verses.text: O Lord, God of Israel, You are just, for we remain a remnant that has escaped, as today. Behold, we are before You in our guilt, for no one can stand before You because of this."
verses.comment: Ezra’s prayer ends with humility: only God’s justice and mercy preserve a people. Compare with Christ’s work, in whom alone anyone can "stand" before God (see Rom. 5:2). The concept of a remnant awaiting God’s mercy prefigures the Church's call to fidelity through all ages.
